name: Ker Sangri
description: A traditional Rajasthani dry curry made from dried desert berries (ker) and beans (sangri), cooked with a blend of local spices, yogurt, and oil. It delivers earthy, tangy, and spicy flavors and pairs perfectly with bajra roti or rice.
preCookingProcess: Soak dried ker and sangri separately in water for 6–8 hours or overnight to rehydrate them.
Boil both ker and sangri in salted water for about 10–12 minutes until tender.
Drain the water and set aside for cooking.

Prepare the masala base: Heat mustard oil in a pan until it smokes lightly, then cool slightly.
Add hing and cumin seeds; let them splutter.
Add boiled ker and sangri, and sauté for 3–4 minutes.
Add spices and curd: In a bowl, whisk curd with turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, salt, and a little water.
Add this mixture to the pan and mix well with ker sangri.
Cook on low flame for 5–7 minutes, stirring occasionally until oil separates.
Finish the curry: Add amchur powder and garam masala. Stir well and cook for another 2 minutes.
Turn off heat and let the dish rest to absorb all flavors.

postCookingProcess: Serve hot with bajra roti, paratha, or steamed rice.
Drizzle with a few drops of ghee for a richer traditional touch.
tipsAndTricks: Always soak ker and sangri properly to remove excess salt and sourness.
Cooking in mustard oil gives authentic flavor.
Add a little jaggery for a sweet-tangy variation.
